title: Pragmatic Ontology Evolution: Reconciling User Requirements and Application Performance

author: Francesco Osborne, Knowledge Media Institute (KMI), Open University (OU)

segmentation: Thank you very much.
So yes, I'm Francesco, I work at KMI with Professor LCMS and I want to talk you about approach for ontology evolution that we develop so.
When we talk about ontology evolution, there are a number of different framework, but most of them agree about three different step.
The first one is that you need to detect the need for devolution.
So for example your ontology is now obsolete because you are missing some concept that you need to have.
The second step is that you need to identify the set of candidate that you need to.
For example importing your ontology.
So for example the new concept that you want to include the young teologi so that will be up to date.

And assessment of these changes and basically we don't want to put everything in ontology.
Want ontology to still have all the overall the compatibility and performance that we had before.

We don't want to break the whole flow of people or machine that are using the ontology.

Specific tasks that you can do with the ontology.

So ideally if you are changing our ontology, we want to produce the best version of the ontology that will work as good as possible on this task.

And of course we also want to provide explanation nobody want to tell other people to tell them what to do without a valid explanation.

This is something that we always have to have in our ontology evolution, because of course we don't want to break stuff.

This ontology by searching outside of the space of para meters so.
